awd_titl_txt: CyberSEES:Type 1: Integrated Management of Data Centers, Electric Grid, and Transportation for Cyber-Enabled Sustainability
awd_abstract_narration:
The future power grid features advanced sensing capabilities, increased level of automation, and faster information exchange enabled by digital communications. With this modernized infrastructure system, energy consumption and management across different sectors are inherently interlinked. This creates abundant new opportunities to coordinate different types of energy consumption for maximized societal benefits. This project is motivated by these opportunities, and seeks to develop an integrated energy management framework to jointly manage power consumption in data centers with other energy consumers surrounding the data center, such as electric vehicles and residential loads. The framework will be developed based on advanced feedback control theory and optimal control theory. The goal is to reduce electricity cost and environmental impacts of the integrated system, and to enable the system to provide green frequency regulation service to the grid to support high penetration of renewable energy resources. 

This project is an early example of how to explore the deep interdependencies between data center power consumption and other nearby energy consumers. Its novelty lies in investigating the potential of using data centers, along with other assets, to jointly provide frequency regulation services to the grid. This will lead to much lower emissions than the traditional approach which is mainly based on coal and natural gas fired generators. The project will also involve a number of education and outreach activities such as participation of undergraduate and under-represented students in research, inclusion of research results into courses, and the involvement of high school students.

por.por_cntn:
The ongoing worldwide deployment of smart grid technologies is creating unprecedented opportunities to control and coordinate different grid assets for maximized societal benefits. Motivated by these opportunities, in this project we developed an integrated control and management framework to synergistically manage the power consumptions of a data center and the Plug-in Electric Vehicles (PEVs) charging loads within a vicinity of the data center. The goal of the framework is to reduce electricity cost and environmental impacts of the integrated system, and to enable the system to provide green frequency regulation service to the grid to support high penetration of renewable energy resources.

The novelty of our research is mainly twofold. First, while previous research often studies PEV charging and data center power management separately, this project is among the first that considers the scenario for which the data center jointly manages its power consumption with the charging of the PEVs of its employees to participate in both the energy and frequency regulation markets. The joint management not only creates new opportunities to save electricity cost, but also increases the overall frequency regulation capacity and improves tracking performance, which can dramatically increase the market revenues of the overall system. The data center can share its market revenue with its employees by providing free charging services or cash rebates for PEV purchases. This will promote PEV adoptions by the employees, and result in a much better carbon footprint of the data center.

Another important outcome is more on the technical side. We developed a market planning strategy that can systematically consider the coupling between the energy and frequency regulation markets and the dynamics of the participating assets. For demand-side participation in the regulation market, the asset will be paid based on the committed regulation capacity, but at the same time will be charged by the energy market for their energy consumption. The regulation price and energy price typically show different trends over a day. To consider the overall revenue, it is not clear whether the energy-use flexibility should be employed to reduce energy consumption or to increase regulation capacity since this often results in different remaining energy-use flexibilities for subsequent planning periods. Our proposed strategy can systematically address this challenge in a realistic setting and brings important insights into the development of realistic power manage strategies for data center and PEVs.

In addition to the integrated power management framework, we have also developed several advanced power management strategies for data center itself and for PEV fleet charging alone. In particular, we have investigated a novel idea of integrating supercapacitor and uninterruptible power supply (UPS) systems in a data center for power shaving. We have shown that such a strategy can greatly reduce both the power infrastructure investment and the electricity bill of a data center. Furthermore, we have also developed a strategy to quantify the aggregate power consumption flexibility of a PEV fleet using a virtual batter model. Such an aggregate model can dramatically simplify the market planning for a PEV fleet and enable a more optimized use of PEV charging flexibility to balance the grid.

The broader impacts of this project include the following. First, our research indicates that jointly managing power consumption of data center with PEV fleet can significantly improve the market revenue of the overall system. This provides more incentives for data centers to actively participate into the energy and ancillary service markets, which can improve market efficiency, reduce the cost of frequency regulation, and contribute to the sustainability of our sociality. Second, the results of this project have been disseminated through several conference and journal publications, including the 32nd International Symposium on Computer Performance, Modeling, Measurements, and Evaluation (Performance 2014), the 6th International Green and Sustainable Computing Conference (IGSC 2015), IEEE Conference on Decision and Control (2016), the IEEE Transactions on Smart Grid, the IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems, and the Elsevier Journal of Sustainable Computing: Informatics and Systems. Furthermore, the project has involved several education activities. In particular, with the support the REU supplement support, we hired one female undergraduate student as a summer intern. Through the intern training, the undergraduate student has been exposed to the state-of-the art research in data center and smart grid, and had a chance to apply the tools and knowledge learned in computer engineering classes to address a real world sustainability issue.
